awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Nanostructured porous and laminate coatings for biodegradable magnesium-based implants with tunable water permeability and improved mechanical properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Biodegradable Mg-based alloys are considered as a great material for implantation without additional secondary surgery for implant removal. They are lightweight, have close to bones physical and mechanical properties, excellent biocompatibility and osseointegration, and they can completely degrade and be replaced by naturally re-grown bones. However, installation of bare Mg-based implants has frequently been accompanied with high initial corrosion rate and hydrogen release burst that can cause variety of post-surgical complications. Therefore, the success of their implementation highly depends on control of corrosion rate and hydrogen release especially during the initial stage of installation. This function can be provided by special coatings having well-controlled water permeability. 

This project supports exploratory work on an untested, but potentially transformative idea for biodegradable Mg implants. It is exploring a new process methodology and underlying mechanism in a new "thin film coatings concept for tunable water transport" - through coating components that are capable of providing targeted/tunable resorption or degradation time. It will study how combining thin, degradable and nanoporous layers into nanolaminate coatings can significantly extend tunable control of initial corrosion rate of Mg-based implants. This project also supports providing URM students at an HBCU with state-of-the-art science and technology training, along with deeper exposure to team-based research and value-creation best practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biodegradable Mg-based alloys are considered as a great material for implantation without additional secondary surgery for implant removal. The success of Mg-based biodegradable implants depends on control of corrosion rate and hydrogen release especially during the initial stage of installation. This functionality can be provided by special degradable coatings having well-controlled temporary protection of implant surface for specific time after surgery.

 In this work we explored an idea to use multilayered biodegradable coatings which have capability to degrade/delaminate layer by layer with fixed time per layer. We have shown that combining thin corroding and nanoporous layers into nanolaminate coatings can produce degradable coating with predictable and repeatable delay of water access to surface of implant material. We have shown that concept can effectively work if nanolaminate system is built by stacking thin degradable/degradable or degradable/na­no­porous bilayers. Approach uses well-established unique capabilities of nanolaminates. Magnetron sputtering is used for depositing thin films having nanoporous or degradable metal-oxide layers of MgO, SiO2, Al2O3, Fe2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, ZnO, and Gd2O­3 altered with layers of degradable or bioactive pure metals Mg, Fe, Gd and Ag. To achieve repeatable degradation time of each bilayer we found that nanoporous layer should be in range 10-50 nm and have nanopores with average distance 20-40 microns between the pores. These requirements were achieved by optimization of deposition techniques. Special optical method was established for performance screening.

Research revealed that best performance was obtained from Al2O3/Mg bilayer laminate coatings. Water permeability can be tuned by thickness of Al2O3 layers in the range 15-40 nm providing resorption delay from 1 to 3 hrs per bilayer. Total degradation of coating is controlled by bilayer delay time multiplied by number of bilayers. With this scientific concept the coating technology can be developed for biodegradable implant applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Sergey Yarmolenko
